channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2017 The New York Times Company

item.title: News Analysis: Fears That Trump’s Visa Ban Betrays Friends and Bolsters Enemies
item.media:description: Syrian refugees arriving in Detroit in 2015. The Muslim world is watching closely as the Trump administration clamps down on immigration.
item.media:credit: Salwan Georges for The New York Times
item.description: Officials, analysts and citizens across Muslim-majority countries said the order was a sign that President Trump sees Islam itself as the problem.
item.dc:creator: DECLAN WALSH

item.title: Warm Welcome for Syrians in a Country About to Ban Them
item.media:description: Volunteers from the Am Shalom synagogue in Glencoe, Ill., waited on Friday at Chicago O’Hare International Airport to greet one of the last Syrian refugee families to be accepted in the United States.
item.media:credit: Hilary Swift for The New York Times
item.description: Volunteers from an Illinois synagogue gathered to greet one of the last Syrian refugee families to be accepted in the United States with the warmest possible welcome.
item.dc:creator: JODI KANTOR

item.title: ‘Dreams Die’ for Refugees on Verge of Coming to U.S. as Trump Closes Door
item.media:description: Sardar Hussain, 16, in front of the United Nations office for refugees in Jakarta, Indonesia. The Afghan boy, who was orphaned by a Taliban bomb, was days away from boarding a plane to the United States.
item.media:credit: Kemal Jufri for The New York Times
item.description: Refugees who had already made it through the vetting procedure to be resettled in the United States reacted with disbelief to President Trump’s ban.
item.dc:creator: ROD NORDLAND, JOE COCHRANE and PATRICK KINGSLEY

item.title: Shabab Militants Attack Kenyan Military Base in Somalia
item.description: Representatives of the Shabab militant group and of the Kenyan Defense Ministry each claimed that they had inflicted heavy losses on the other side.
item.dc:creator: HUSSEIN MOHAMED

item.title: Trump and Mexican President Speak by Phone Amid Dispute Over Wall
item.media:description: President Enrique Peña Nieto of Mexico with Donald J. Trump in August, when Mr. Trump visited the country during the presidential campaign.
item.media:credit: Henry Romero/Reuters
item.description: The two spoke for about an hour, and both presidents made an effort to say that the call had been productive. However, they stood their ground on their positions.
item.dc:creator: KIRK SEMPLE

item.title: As Migrants Strain Border Towns, Pressure Builds on Mexico to Act
item.media:description: Haitian migrants during an evening prayer at Iglesia Central del Nazareno, a church sheltering Haitian women and children in Tijuana, Mexico.
item.media:credit: Meghan Dhaliwal for The New York Times
item.description: With shelters in Tijuana already teeming with Haitians, some advocates fear President Trump’s plan could spur a far bigger crisis that Mexico may not be able to handle.
item.dc:creator: KIRK SEMPLE
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations

item.title: Taliban, Collecting Bills for Afghan Utilities, Tap New Revenue Sources
item.media:description: Taliban in Ghazni Province, Afghanistan, in 2015. The insurgency has diversified its revenue.
item.media:credit: Reuters
item.description: As militants have taken over increasingly large areas in the past two years, they have found ways beyond the illicit drug trade to make money.
item.dc:creator: MUJIB MASHAL and NAJIM RAHIM

item.title: As Climate Change Accelerates, Floating Cities Look Like Less of a Pipe Dream
item.media:description: A rendering of the artificial floating island project in French Polynesia. The project is being put forward by a California nonprofit, the Seasteading Institute, which has raised about $2.5 million from more than 1,000 interested donors.
item.media:credit: Seasteading Institute
item.description: A costly plan to build floating islands shows how climate change is pushing the search for innovative solutions, but some critics ask who will ultimately benefit.
item.dc:creator: MIKE IVES

item.title: Many Japanese Look for a Shift to Female Heirs to Throne
item.media:description: Emperor Akihito of Japan in Tokyo this month. Many feel any change in the law to allow his abdication should also permit female successors.
item.media:credit: Koji Sasahara/Associated Press
item.description: As the governing party considers allowing Emperor Akihito to retire, many in the public believe the law should be permanently changed to admit women as heirs to the throne.
item.dc:creator: MOTOKO RICH

item.title: Ten Centuries Later, a Pope and Knights Do Battle
item.media:description: Pope Francis during his meeting in June with the Knights of Malta leader, Matthew Festing. The pope asked Mr. Festing to resign this past week and announced that a papal delegate would take his place.
item.media:credit: Gabriel Bouys/Agence France-Presse, via Associated Press
item.description: A Vatican rift has spilled into the Knights of Malta, a sovereign order. Freemasons, beware.
item.dc:creator: JASON HOROWITZ

item.title: The Questions That Could Reshape a Worried Europe in 2017
item.media:description: A pedestrian walks past by a giant poster of a Euro coin near Waterloo in London this month.
item.media:credit: Facundo Arrizabalaga/European Pressphoto Agency
item.description: The rise of populism, economic threats and the uncertainty of relations with the Trump administration are sources of turbulence for Europe.
item.dc:creator: RICK GLADSTONE

item.title: What in the World: Polish City to Give Tom Hanks the Car That Put It on the Auto Map
item.media:description: A gathering of Fiat 126p enthusiasts in Krakow, Poland. “The Maluch was the beginning of an automotive revolution in Poland,” said Jacek Krywult, the mayor of Bielsko-Biala, Poland, where the car was made.
item.media:credit: Artur Widak/NurPhoto, via Getty Images
item.description: The Maluch, built in Bielsko-Biala from the early 1970s to 2000, has developed a following that apparently includes at least one prominent fan.
item.dc:creator: RICK LYMAN

item.title: Mongolians Demonstrate in Capital Demanding Action on Smog
item.description: Thousands of Mongolians stood in frigid weather on Saturday for the second time this winter to demand that the government strengthen its response to the smog that routinely blankets Ulan Bator.
item.dc:creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: ‘How Do I Get Back Home?’ Iranians Turned Away From Flights to U.S.
item.description: Three airlines shuttling passengers between Iran and the United States had stopped allowing Iranians with visas or even permanent residence cards to board their planes.
item.dc:creator: THOMAS ERDBRINK

item.title: The Neediest Cases: An Iraqi Family Split by the Vicissitudes of Asylum
item.media:description: Maha al-Obaidi in Queens with Tameem al-Kadhi, left, and Qaed al-Qadhi, two of her three sons. Two others remain overseas.
item.media:credit: Stephen Speranza for The New York Times
item.description: Though theirs is an immigrant success story in some respects, with sons working and one owning a business, Maha al-Obaidi grieves that half her family remains half a world away.
item.dc:creator: JOHN OTIS and RANA F. SWEIS
item.category: New York Times Neediest Cases Fund

item.title: The Interpreter: Trump Administration Holds Off on Issuing U.N. Funding Order
item.media:description: Nikki R. Haley on Friday at the United Nations. The Trump administration is delaying its plans to issue two executive orders that would reduce funding to the world body.
item.media:credit: Justin Lane/European Pressphoto Agency
item.description: A draft order to reduce American funding to the world body, and another that would lead to a review of multinational treaties, have been delayed to allow further study.
item.dc:creator: MAX FISHER

item.title: In Iran, Shock and Bewilderment Over Trump Visa Crackdown
item.media:description: A customs checkpoint for foreign travelers arriving at Miami International Airport.
item.media:credit: Joe Raedle/Getty Images
item.description: The new administration’s freeze on visas for a targeted group of countries could provide an early test of its relationship with Tehran.
item.dc:creator: THOMAS ERDBRINK and JEFFREY GETTLEMAN

item.title: Canada Today: Trump Is a Blessing and a Curse for Trudeau
item.media:description: Chick Webster at home in Mattawa, Ontario, this month. He played for the Rangers in the 1949-50 season and is the oldest living former NHL player.
item.media:credit: Ian Willms for The New York Times
item.description: Prime Minister Justin Trudeau faces a balancing act over the resurrected Keystone XL pipeline, and plays down the effects of possible Nafta changes for Canada.
item.dc:creator: IAN AUSTEN

item.title: Duterte’s Free Birth-Control Order Is Latest Skirmish With Catholic Church
item.media:description: Children playing in Happyland. President Rodrigo Duterte says access to reproductive health services is vital to reducing poverty.
item.media:credit: Dondi Tawatao for The New York Times
item.description: The Philippine president’s demand gives clear guidance to local officials, after challenges by the church and others kept a 2012 law from taking full effect.
item.dc:creator: AURORA ALMENDRAL

item.title: Trump Cites Israel’s ‘Wall’ as Model. The Analogy Is Iffy.
item.media:description: The West Bank barrier in East Jerusalem.
item.media:credit: Daniel Berehulak for The New York Times
item.description: Yes, Israel did build a West Bank barrier. But it was to deter terrorists. It was never intended to stop all Palestinians from crossing into Israel.
item.dc:creator: ISABEL KERSHNER

item.title: France Bans Free Soda Refills in Attack on Obesity
item.media:description: A soft drink bottling operation in Clamart, France, near Paris.
item.media:credit: Lionel Bonaventure/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.description: The regulation is the latest attempt to tackle what the government called a relentless rise in the national obesity rate.
item.dc:creator: KIMIKO de FREYTAS-TAMURA

item.title: Russians Charged With Treason Worked in Office Linked to Election Hacking
item.description: The appearance of news on the arrests in four prominent publications suggested that the Kremlin may be prepared to reveal more about the matter.
item.dc:creator: SCOTT SHANE, DAVID E. SANGER and ANDREW E. KRAMER

item.title: Trump Meets Theresa May of Britain as He Weighs Lifting Russia Sanctions
item.description: As he hosts his first foreign leader since taking office, President Trump is contemplating lifting sanctions against Russia despite European objections.
item.dc:creator: PETER BAKER

item.title: Nikki Haley Puts U.N. on Notice: U.S. Is ‘Taking Names’
item.description: President Trump’s new ambassador to the United Nations said the United States would respond accordingly to those who “don’t have our back.”
item.dc:creator: SOMINI SENGUPTA

item.title: The Saturday Profile: Gary Lineker, Soccer Hero, Dips a Toe Into Post-Brexit British Politics
item.media:description: Gary Lineker says he understands the anger in Britain. “But all of a sudden we’re blaming all the ills of the country on refugees and foreigners. It’s just wrong.”
item.media:credit: Andrew Testa for The New York Times
item.description: Gary Lineker, the popular host of the BBC’s “Match of the Day,” has emerged as a leading critic of the exit from the European Union and of anti-immigrant views.
item.dc:creator: KATRIN BENNHOLD

item.title: Sinosphere: At Hong Kong New Year Fair, Defiance Gives Way to Resignation
item.media:description: Joshua Wong, a leader of the pro-democracy Umbrella Movement and a co-founder of the Demosisto party, spoke from the party’s stall at the Lunar New Year fair in Victoria Park in Hong Kong on Thursday.
item.media:credit: Lam Yik Fei for The New York Times
item.description: Along with fish balls and flowers, vendors in Victoria Park sold a game with a predetermined set of outcomes, a nod to the Beijing-directed selection of the city’s leader.
item.dc:creator: ALAN WONG

item.title: Sinosphere: Surviving Chinese New Year With the Family: A Musical How-To
item.description: A song, spreading fast online, offers a bit of relief for those dashing home to celebrate the Lunar New Year only to face relentless questions about their lives.
item.dc:creator: DIDI KIRSTEN TATLOW

item.title: ‘I Didn’t Want to Lose My Identity’: 16,000 Readers Reflect on Their Surnames
item.media:description: Katherine Yuk from Toronto was one of more than 16,000 readers who responded when The New York Times asked women around the world why they kept or changed their surnames when they married.
item.media:credit: Ian Willms for The New York Times
item.description: The Times asked women around the world why they had kept or changed their surnames when they married. For many, the decision carried significant weight.
item.dc:creator: HANNA INGBER

item.title: 15 of the Best Journals by Our Reporters Around the World
item.media:description: A man folding blankets that are rented out to the homeless in Delhi.
item.media:credit: Daniel Berehulak for The New York Times
item.description: The conversational and visual on-the-ground reports offered a glimpse of captivating people and places, from a “sleep mafia” in Delhi to a monastery seeking salvation in beer.
item.dc:creator: Compiled by BARBARA TIERNEY

item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: Egypt’s Rickety Dictatorship
item.media:credit: Mitch Blunt
item.description: Six years after the start of the Egyptian revolution, President Abdel Fattah el-Sisi’s regime is more vulnerable than it appears.
item.dc:creator: JACK SHENKER

item.title: Op-Ed Columnist: The Closing of Trump’s America
item.media:description: An anti-Trump protester in New York in 2015 wearing a button that reads, “Keep our Muslim neighbors SAFE” and holding a pocket copy of the U.S. Constitution.
item.media:credit: Karsten Moran for The New York Times
item.description: A rough translation of “America First” is Muslims last.
item.dc:creator: ROGER COHEN

item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: The Exorcist of Russia
item.media:description: Nikita Mikhalkov at the Yeltsin Center in Yekaterinburg, Russia, in December. His image of Russia is that of a besieged fortress under constant threat of attack.
item.media:credit: Donat Sorokin\TASS, via Getty Images
item.description: A nationalist friend of Vladimir Putin promotes a version of history with an enormous chip on its shoulder.
item.dc:creator: DOUGLAS SMITH
